Birds Encouraged Him,"" from Jason Lytle's new record ""Yours Truly, The Commuter."" And he was playing along with Rusty Miller who's supporting him on tour out at NPR West in Culver City.
Time, I think, for one last email question.
This is from Shane(ph) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
Jason, can you talk about the children's choir featured on your MySpace page?
What was that experience?
Apparently, there is a music teacher somewhere in France who likes to impose his record collection on his students.
And he's done a few of them.
He did one with Liam Finn and a couple of other people that, I don't know, just - basically, he took some Granddaddy songs and he taught 10 or 15 of them to his students.
And he did these, kind of, amateur recordings of them.
And it's really sweet stuff because it's - I mean, first off it's the flattering aspect of it.
Mm-hmm.

You know, hearing your songs performed by these kids who are just barely pulling it off on the instruments, but then choir part of it as well is - all these French children, who I think range in between 10 and 14 years old, and it just puts this really sweet, eerie, foreign twist onto the songs.
Hmm.
Well, Jason, thanks so much for your time today.
Appreciate it.
Good luck on tour.
Thank you very much for having me.
And good luck with your new CD, ""Yours Truly, The Commuter."" Thanks as well to Rusty Miller who's supporting him on tour.
They joined us today from the studios at NPR West.
Our thanks also to engineer Leo del Aguila for his help with this performance.
Saddam Hussein returns to a Baghdad courtroom today for the opening of his second trial.
In this one Saddam is accused of genocide and war crimes against the Kurds.
In 1988 at least 50,000 Kurds were killed.
Thousands of others were rounded up and sent to detention camps, and villages were decimated by chemical attacks.
It was part of the Iraqi army campaign known as Anfal, Arabic for the Spoils of War.
Saddam refused to enter a plea in the courtroom today.
The chief judge entered a not guilty plea on Saddam's behalf.
Mahmoud Othman, a Kurdish member of the Iraqi parliament, joins me now.
And welcome to the program.
Thank you.
It has been nearly 20 years since the attacks on the Kurds, what's your reaction to seeing Saddam stand trial now?
Well, I think it has taken too long.
We thought that after toppling the regime we'd have the trial soon.
But still now we are happy, we and all the victims of Anfal, and also Iraqi people in general.
They're happy to see this trial is there.
We hope it will be just, it will be transparent, and we hope that these people will be punished finally, according to what the court decides.
Regarding Saddam's trial, Human Rights Watch has been very critical of the Iraqi justice system, saying the Iraqi High Tribunal is unable to conduct a genocide trial.
For example, the group says none of the judges or lawyers has shown an understanding of criminal law.
Saddam's lawyers can't even be protected.
Three of them have been assassinated.
What do you think of the criticism from Human Rights Watch?
It's unfortunate that the trial takes place at this situation in Iraq when the situation is very bad.
People are not protected.
But at the same time I think maybe our judges, they don't know exactly all what concerns genocide and international laws and principle.
But still, I think they're professional, they're not politized(ph), and they will try the best they can to have fair and just trial, as much as they can.
I think they will be finally punished one way or another.
If Saddam is found guilty, what kind of punishment would you like to see him receive?
Well, I don't have anything specific.
I think the court should decide on that.
We hope there will be also information revealed about who helped Saddam.
Many countries outside were helping Saddam when he committed these crimes.
We hope those countries will be revealed.
That's very important for our people.
Which countries do you suspect helped him?
John Yoo is now professor of law at the University of California at Berkeley and former deputy assistant attorney general at the Department of Justice.
He's with us from a studio on the campus at the University of California at Berkeley.
Nice to talk to you again.
Hi.
Thanks for having me back on.
(Soundbite of applause)
By all accounts, Ed Welburn is quiet, focused and congenial.
And after 40 years of working for GM, he's been responsible for hundreds of designers and dozens of cars on the road right now.
Now, Welburn's passion for cars started early.
He didn't come out of the womb thinking about cars, but by the time he was 3, he was drawing them.
And before he could properly tie his shoes, he was fixing bikes in the backyard.
At age 8, my parents took me to the Philadelphia Auto Show.
And as we walked in, I saw this concept car on display.
I was already crazy about cars.
It was 1958, and the car was the Cadillac Cyclone, a concept car.
Now, it's the '50s - right?
- so think rocket ship on wheels.
Some 60 years later, it still looks hella futuristic.
And then I saw that car, and that car took me from being crazy about cars to, this is it.
This is what I want to do.
To be clear, it wasn't that he just wanted to design cars.
He wanted to design crazy new-age cars, cars like the Cyclone.
His mother said, you can't just play with cars, though.
You have to read about them.
And it was through those car magazines that I found out where that car came from.
And at age 11, I wrote a letter to GM Design telling them I want to be a car designer when I grow up.
What courses should I take?
What do I need to do?
And General Motors - they wrote back.
The head of personnel sent Welburn brochures to the top design schools.
Now, they knew he was 11 years old, but they took him seriously.
And later, as he began to apply to schools, his youthful enthusiasm met the reality of being an ambitious, smart black man in the 1960s.

Senior year, when you're applying to design schools and you make it through the first wave because your grade point average was excellent and then you present your portfolio, design school after design school that was on that list from GM rejected me.
And that was, like, this big shock to my system.
I mean I'm on this mission to become a car designer.
Then all of a sudden, I'm getting rejection letter after rejection letter.
Sixteen schools in all rejected Welburn.
To be clear, design schools lead directly to jobs designing cars.
Students are often recruited in their freshman year.
Again, Bill Pretzer, curator with the Smithsonian National Museum of African-American History and Culture...
There's a phrase in the African-American - many African-American communities called making a way out of no way.
That is, if confronted with obstacles, you still find a way.
And this was a family that consistently found a way to make a way out of no way.
(SOUNDBITE OF ROBERTA FLACK SONG, ""TRYIN' TIMES"")
The Welburn family way - they enrolled their son at Howard University in the art school.
He entered the historically black college at a powerful moment at Howard and in the country.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""TRYIN' TIMES"")
(Singing) Tryin' times is what the world is talking about.
You've got confusion.
And you could hear Roberta Flack in the music studio studying.
You go down the hall to the - I would use the shop in the theater area, and there's Debbie Allen, Phylicia Rashad there studying.
We were all students together.
That was an incredible environment in which to grow.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""TRYIN' TIMES"")
(Singing) Out of hand.
So Howard University created a car design program just for Ed Welburn.
And in his junior year, he got a coveted internship at GM's sculpture studio.
Yes, GM has a sculpture studio.
Welburn began making models and building concept cars.
And at GM, he stuck out like a sculptor at a car plant.
You know, I'm not so sure that the vision for many of our products was as clear as it is today.
There certainly wasn't the collaboration.
